title: EPISTOLA Laura E. Washburn
html:
EPISTOLA Laura E. Washburn

I would like to make a couple of comments on articles in the Autumn 1988 issue [XV,2]. Re the article on Cuthbert, Dickens uses intercourse to mean 'communication between people' in A Christmas Carol when Scrooge says “I will not be the man I must have been but for this intercourse” to the third Spirit.

I would think that the words grand and stretch would be known to more people than two of the words the author gives as being familiar (chippy and hootch).

Incidentally, I seem to recall reading somewhere that skins as slang for 'dollars' dates from frontier days when trappers used animal skins as currency, and is therefore much older than early 20th-century Harlem.

[Laura E. Washburn, Acton, Massachusetts]
